resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: This issue has been validated/reproduced, but has not been prioritized yet.
status.name: Confirmed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
I clicked on the dashboard and saw no new numeric values pop up (busy indicators were there briefly). I clicked on volumes and on that screen, there was a notice that the session had timed out. Refreshing the dashboard should at least notify the user, but could possibly redirect back to the login screen.
I think we need to improve this UX.
fields.summary: No session timeout notification during CLC fetches via XHR

comments.body: [~dkavanagh] We're handling session timeouts in XHR responses thanks to code at https://github.com/eucalyptus/koala/blob/develop/koala/views/__init__.py#L74 (probably should be updated to use the new JSONResponse class we recently added), although it's up to the $http get/post error handler in the client-side JS to properly notify the user.

[~Rocky]: We'll need to detect Beaker session timeouts and display the appropriate notice.  Beaker doesn't provide any hooks for this AFAICT, but a recent post to the pylons-discuss mailing list points to a possible workaround (see https://gist.github.com/kamalgill/9103505 )

The relevant pylons-discuss thread is at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/pylons-discuss/9zDnLK15Wks , although it discusses file-based Beaker sessions, so not sure how useful it might be to handle cookie-based session timeouts.  May be worth a look though.

[~jloza] We are now capturing session timeout notices from the backend in a centralized way thanks to [~dkavanagh]'s work on GUI-554 (https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/399). 

The question is whether we want to display a session timeout notice when the browser is idle.  If we only want to display the timeout when the user navigates to a new page, there will be no further work required.  However, requiring that we display a timeout exactly when the timeout is reached, regardless of user interaction, may require push notifications or a polling mechanism from the client, either approach potentially requiring a significant amount of work.
[~dkavanagh] Does the scope of this ticket refer to token timeout notices from the backend, or does it refer to idle timeouts, or both?
re-reading my description, I think it refers to the back end 403 errors.
[~dkavanagh] Ok, may I reassign this one to you then?  We can open a new ticket for the idle timeout notice and will assign that one to [~Rocky].

[~kgill] do you still need input from me here? I would prefer this to happen when idle if possible, but if we have to we can write a ticket for that and push to 4.1 if absolutely necessary. Let me know!

[~jloza] I think we're good w.r.t. this ticket since it doesn't include idle timeouts within its scope.  Will open a separate ticket for handling idle timeouts and target that for 4.1 since it's a fairly involved effort.
Fixed thanks to work by [~dkavanagh] in https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/399 and https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/485
[~Rocky] Sorry for the confusion here. I meant to move this to QA a while ago since it was addressed (in somewhat-related tickets) in pull requests 399 and 485

1) let session time out
2) click on dashboard

should toss you out to the login screen

[~jloza] To facilitate QA'ing this one, bump down the expiration timeout setting in console.ini to the following (for a 10 sec timeout)...

session.cookie_expires = 10

Session timed out, clicking the dash kicked me out to the login page, but there was no message of any kind that my session had timed out. 

Can we please display some text on the login page when the session times out that says "Your session has timed out. Please log in again."

[~Rocky]: The session timeout settings are in the following section of console.ini…

{code}
# Idle timeout (1800 sec = 30 min)
session.timeout = 1800
# Absolute timeout (43200 sec = 12 hours)
session.cookie_expires = 43200
{code}

The relevant one for this ticket is session.cookie_expires.  Setting that to a few seconds should help w.r.t. troubleshooting.
I can reproduce the issue about 50% of the time when I try.  Either way, I have some code here now that *should* resolve it... mostly testing now.
Looks good - my current messages was simply, "You let your session expire? what HAVE you DONE????"   ;-)
[~Rocky] HA! Perfect!
hey [~Rocky], We decided in the bug scrub today that if you can make the message for this what [~kgill] indicated in the comments, that is probably enough for this ticket for 4.0...
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/705
kicked back for updates based on [~kgill]'s comments in PR.
FYI not timing out on instance detail page.

I've been testing session timeout and try as I might, I cannot get a decent timeout status to return in this case. It seems that the container (pyramid) is trapping the condition before it gets to our view and simply returning the login page w/ 200 status code. Need to know more about how pyramid/beaker is handling session timeout.

We need more time to fix the issue on the instance detail page where a timeout would occur if/when the instance is in a transitional state.  We have a separate ticket open (GUI-994) to address that issue.  Suggesting GUI-263 be limited to displaying the proper notice ("Your session has timed out. This may be due to inactivity…") when a timeout occurs via an XHR call.

Note to QA, a good place to confirm this would be any of the landing pages.  Set the session.cookie_expires to 900 seconds (15 min is the minimum timeout for the back-end), don't change the idle timeout (leave session.timeout at 30 min), and click the reload button (the green one on the page, not the browsers's reload) on a landing page.
Thanks, [~kgill]!
Setting session.cookie_expires = 900 in console.ini and hitting the green reload button on the security groups landing page after the 15 min timeout does not display the timeout notification.

[~dkavanagh]: I thought we were going to modify https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/blob/develop/eucaconsole/views/login.py#L69 to make the token duration 60 seconds *less* than the cookie_expires setting to allow the 403 from the CLC to surface prior to the cookie expiration?
I tried that, but it didn't help.
[~dkavanagh]: Ah, I think the issue may be isolated to the security groups landing page, which doesn't wrap the json view code in the boto_error_handler context manager.
If you remember, we had this issue on the instance view during smart update.
[~dkavanagh] Yeah, that page too.  I was referring to the security groups landing page being the only *landing page* affected.  There are probably a few others affected that aren't landing pages.
[~dkavanagh]: Looks as though the Images landing page is also missing the boto_error_handler wrapper, which will probably manifest this issue there as well.
Snapshots landing page JSON view is also missing the boto_error_handler wrapper

It was impossible to catch the timeout because the container caused it, not
a CLC call. So the with statement wouldn't help till we figured out how to
stop the container from timing out he session without calling the view.
On May 21, 2014 5:15 PM, "Kamal Gill (JIRA)" <jira@eucalyptus.atlassian.net>

[~dkavanagh]: I'm not clear what you mean by "the container caused it".  Testing the timeout on the security groups landing page returns the login page as the JSON response, so the timeout appears to be from a 403 response, but the issue on that landing page (and possibly elsewhere) is that the view isn't returning a 403 status code via a JSON response since it isn't wrapped in the boto_error_handler code.

When we were in Austin last week, I was testing this and mentioned how the login page was the response to the JSON call. I also mentioned how our view was never instantiated, so our code never had a chance to call the CLC or catch an error. The problem is that the container is responding on behalf of our application because it thinks the session has expired. That is why I said I wanted to look at the beaker.session code more closely to understand why that happens. If we don't have control over the session, we can't be sure our XHR calls will be answered properly.
I thought this was discussed as a 4.0.1 during the UI weekly today. Perhaps that's another that deals with the same session timeout problem?

[~dkavanagh]: ok, will scope this for 4.0.1.  Do you have a list for the docs team for the places where we aren't handling the session timeout?  I've listed a few in the comments above (images, snapshots, and security groups landing page, instance detail page).  Is that list complete, or are there other places where you've observed this?
I don't have an exhaustive list, but any place we do an XHR call, so landing page refresh (manual or smart), detail page smart refresh, and most functions on the user detail page.

[~dkavanagh]: Thank you.  For the landing page refresh, we should distinguish between a browser-based refresh, a smart refresh, and a refresh using the green reload button.  The browser refresh isn't affected by this issue, while the latter two are AFAICT.

Hi - I was asked to put this in the known issues of the release notes. After reading through the ticket updates, I am not sure what information I need to describe in the documentation. I understand there is a lack of session timeout notification, but does the user know what "during CLC fetch via XHR" means? or are they just simply clicking on the dashboard and nothing happens until they get kicked out and back to the login screen? Thanks!
[~tvo]: The latter (clicking on the dashboard and nothing happens until they get kicked out…) is a better description for the release notes.

[~tvo]: Just another note that the default timeout for the admin user is one hour, while the timeout for the non-admin users is 12 hours (assuming the idle timeout, which defaults to 30 minutes, hasn't been reached).
Thank you [~kgill] for the additional info! This helps a lot!
fixed by https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/748
Pull request 748 merged
I did a quick test on this with the dashboard.  I let it sit for 30 mins and tried clicking on the on the Dashboard link.  I was immediately brought to the login screen.
